title: Scenario 4: Breast
diagnosis_topic: Growing Breast Mass with Skin Changes
setup_script: A 52-year-old female presents to your clinic with a right breast mass that she noticed 3 months ago but delayed seeking care due to the COVID-19 pandemic. She reports the mass has been growing steadily and is now painful. She denies nipple discharge but has noticed some skin dimpling. She has no previous breast biopsies and no family history of breast or ovarian cancer. On examination, you palpate a 5 cm firm, fixed mass in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast with overlying skin dimpling. You also palpate firm, enlarged lymph nodes in the right axilla. How would you proceed with this patient?

dynamic_flow.reply: Mammogram and ultrasound show a 5.2 cm spiculated mass with microcalcifications in the right upper outer quadrant, suspicious for malignancy (BIRADS 5). Ultrasound confirms multiple enlarged right axillary lymph nodes with loss of fatty hilum.
Core needle biopsy of the breast mass shows invasive ductal carcinoma, grade 3, ER/PR negative, HER2 positive. FNA of an axillary node is positive for metastatic carcinoma.
CT chest/abdomen/pelvis and bone scan show no evidence of distant metastases.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discusses surgical options immediately
dynamic_flow.reply: Given the size of the tumor, skin involvement, and positive axillary nodes, what approach would you recommend for this patient?

You refer the patient to medical oncology and she receives neoadjuvant chemotherapy with HER2-targeted therapy. After 6 months, the tumor has decreased to 1.5 cm by imaging and the skin changes have resolved. What is your surgical plan now?
What factors influence your decision between breast conservation and mastectomy in this case?
What type of mastectomy would you recommend and why? What would you discuss regarding reconstruction options?
How would you manage the axilla in this patient after neoadjuvant therapy?

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident does not address the possibility of pathologic complete response
dynamic_flow.reply: The final pathology shows no residual invasive cancer in the breast specimen, but 2 of 15 lymph nodes are positive for metastatic disease. How does this change your recommendations for adjuvant therapy and follow-up?

critical_decision_points: Appropriate initial diagnostic workup for suspected breast cancer
Recognition of locally advanced disease requiring multidisciplinary approach
Surgical planning after neoadjuvant therapy (breast conservation vs. mastectomy)
Management of the axilla after neoadjuvant therapy
Discussion of reconstruction options if mastectomy is performed

diagnostic_reasoning: Inadequate diagnostic workup for suspected breast cancer
Basic workup but missing important elements or incorrect sequencing
Appropriate diagnostic workup including imaging and tissue diagnosis
Comprehensive diagnostic approach with appropriate staging
Excellent diagnostic reasoning with thorough workup, appropriate staging, and consideration of genetic testing
clinical_judgment: Recommends immediate surgery without consideration of neoadjuvant therapy
Considers neoadjuvant therapy but lacks understanding of indications or benefits
Appropriately recommends neoadjuvant therapy for locally advanced disease
Good clinical judgment in multidisciplinary approach, surgical planning after neoadjuvant therapy
Excellent judgment throughout with appropriate sequencing of therapy, surgical planning, and consideration of patient factors and preferences
communication: Disorganized presentation, unable to articulate management plan clearly
Somewhat organized but incomplete explanation of treatment options
Clear communication of diagnosis, staging, and treatment plan
Well-organized, systematic presentation with clear explanation of multidisciplinary approach
Exceptionally clear communication, excellent organization, articulates complex decision-making and addresses patient-centered concerns
surgical_knowledge: Inadequate knowledge of surgical management of breast cancer
Basic understanding of surgical options but limited knowledge of current guidelines
Adequate knowledge of surgical approach for locally advanced breast cancer
Good knowledge of surgical options, axillary management after neoadjuvant therapy
Excellent knowledge of current guidelines, technical considerations for surgery after neoadjuvant therapy, and management of the axilla
professionalism: Does not involve multidisciplinary team appropriately
Minimal consideration of patient preferences or multidisciplinary approach
Appropriate consideration of patient preferences and multidisciplinary approach
Good communication with multidisciplinary team, consideration of patient preferences
Excellent patient-centered approach, clear communication with multidisciplinary team, addresses psychosocial aspects of care
